title: Microsoft wins JEDI battle but Amazon could return fire
text:
Microsoft Corp. shares ticked higher Monday after the Department of Defense awarded the tech giant a $10 billion cloud-services contract, thwarting rival Amazon.com Inc. and prompting analysts to say the move was further validation of Azure as AWS’s fiercest competitor.

Microsoft MSFT, +2.46% shares rose 2.5% to $144.24 in recent activity, while Amazon AMZN, +0.89% shares gained 0.8% to $1,775.90. In comparison the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.49% was up 0.5%, the S&P 500 index SPX, +0.56% was up 0.6%, and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, +1.01% was up 1.1%.

Late Friday, the Department of Defense announced that Microsoft’s Azure cloud service would get the so-called JEDI Cloud contract, which will allow Azure to “provide enterprise level, commercial Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) and Platform as a Service (PaaS) to support Department of Defense business and mission operations.”

Amazon, which had been considered the favorite, and Microsoft were the last two competitors for the bid after Oracle Corp. ORCL, +0.87% and International Business Machines Corp. IBM, +0.39% had been eliminated. Oracle had vowed to appeal its elimination.

But Cowen analyst Nick Yako said the fight may not be over.

“Given all of the twists and turns of this seemingly mundane ‘commercial’ purchase (including lawsuits, Presidential & Congressional interest and a SecDef-level review & then recusal), we would not firmly count this in the Microsoft win column until the protest window has closed at the Government Accountability Office,” Yako said, citing similar actions in the past.

“The next phase of this saga could be an Amazon protest or even a lawsuit after the company is debriefed by the Pentagon on the rationale for its loss,” Yako said. “The animus between President Trump and Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos raises the level of intrigue (especially considering CNBC reported quotes in an upcoming book from a speechwriter of former SecDef Jim Mattis that purports Trump wanted Amazon to lose).”

Brad Reback called it a “great win” for Microsoft in that it “validate” Azure which continues to gain on AWS. It is estimated Microsoft could make about $210 million in the first two years of the contract.

“We think there is plenty of opportunity for similar size (or even larger) deals like this available across enterprises — and that in coming years, Azure has the potential to be Microsoft’s largest revenue stream and profit pool,” Reback said.

“We believe organizations are still in the earliest stages of their cloud migration and as they continue to digitally transform in coming years, the potential for deals of this size, and higher, will become more common place,” Reback said.

“As context, two companies under our coverage list, Datadog DDOG, -2.97% and MongoDB MDB, +1.78% , spend roughly $75M and $45M per year with AWS, and they are still relatively small companies (each under $400M in revenue).”

Bernstein analyst Mark Moerdler, who has an outperform rating on Microsoft and a $167 price target, said the initial impact of the contract will be small on Azure but the long-term gain is what investors should focus on, allowing Azure to increase scale and improve margins.

“We see this as incrementally positive to our Microsoft thesis,” Moerdler said. “We also see this as incrementally positive for Citrix CTXS, +1.16%, Oracle, SAP SAP, +0.68% and VMware VMW, -1.68% whose platform software is available on Azure,” Moerdler said.

Of the 33 analysts that cover Microsoft, a whopping 31 have overweight or buy ratings, and two have hold ratings, along with a target price of $161.03, according to FactSet data.
